document.docTitle: Aphaenogaster olympica Borowiec & Salata, 2014, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of Mediterranean members of the Aphaenogaster cecconii group (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), with description of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of Mediterranean members of the Aphaenogaster cecconii group (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), with description of four new species

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Named after its locus typicus, Olympos village.

Aphaenogaster olympica
sp. nov. 9
, Worker dorsal. 10 , Worker lateral (scale bar = 1 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology. The habitat preferences are as in
Aphaenogaster cecconii
. The foraging workers are found in small caverns, at entries to large caves, cracks in rock walls of northern exposure, and inside large porous limestone rocks in shady parts of mountain streams.

Discussion.
Aphaenogaster olympica
sp. nov.
,
Aphaenogaster jolantae
sp. nov.
and
Aphaenogaster equestris
sp. nov.
are together easily distinguished from the other three species of the
A. cecconii
group by the head lacking a narrowed neck with flared collar.
Aphaenogaster equestris
differs in having the body mostly rusty-yellow and the sculpture of the head stronger, with the head surface partly dull.
Aphaenogaster jolantae
is very similar and differs by the characters outlined in the key.
